Based on your preferences, I would recommend "The Giver" as an excellent dystopian film that deals with themes of power, control, and freedom.

"The Giver" is directed by Garth Jennings, who also wrote the screenplay. The movie stars Jeff Bridges as a man named Jonas, who lives in a totalitarian society called 'Glimpse' where everything is controlled, and people are told what to think about.
Jonas's life changes when he meets one of the few people who have not been "brainwashed" by the government and they tell him that there once was a time before everything was controlled by the government, when everyone had freedom and choice, but now it has all been taken away from them by the government.

The movie has won several awards and is highly regarded by both critics and audiences alike.

Based on the preferences and cues provided, I would recommend "We the Living" by Ayn Rand as a highly engaging and thought-provoking film.

The movie tells the story of three people who live in a world dominated by fear. The three individuals are Kira, who wants to be a builder, and the two men who love her  - Leo, an aristocrat, and Andrei, a Communist. In their tensely dramatic story, Ayn Rand shows what the theories of Communism mean in practice.

Overall, "We the Living" is a highly engaging and thought-provoking film that offers a challenging and thought-provoking look at politics and social systems.
